content.description: <math alttext="C d F 2 solid is in equilibrium with C d with a positive 2 charge aqueous plus 2 F with a negative 1 charge aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CdF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Cd</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: A saturated aqueous solution of <math alttext="C d F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CdF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is prepared. The equilibrium in the solution is represented above. In the solution, <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of C d with a positive 2 charge equals 0.0585 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cd</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.0585</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of F with a negative 1 charge equals 0.117 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.117</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Some <math alttext="0.90 molar N a F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.90</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is added to the saturated solution. Which of the following identifies the molar solubility of <math alttext="C d F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CdF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in pure water and explains the effect that the addition of <math alttext="N a F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has on this solubility?

choices.label: The molar solubility of <math alttext="C d F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CdF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in pure water is <math alttext="0.0585 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0585</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and adding <math alttext="N a F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> decreases this solubility because the equilibrium shifts to favor the precipitation of some <math alttext="C d F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CdF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The molar solubility of <math alttext="C d F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CdF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in pure water is <math alttext="0.0585 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0585</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and adding <math alttext="N a F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has no effect on the solubility because only changes in temperature can increase or decrease the molar solubility of an ionic solid.

The molar solubility of <math alttext="C d F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CdF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in pure water is <math alttext="0.117 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.117</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and adding <math alttext="N a F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> decreases this solubility because the equilibrium shifts to favor the precipitation of some <math alttext="C d F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CdF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The molar solubility of <math alttext="C d F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CdF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in pure water is <math alttext="0.176 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.176</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and adding <math alttext="N a F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increases this solubility because the <math alttext="N a with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions displace the <math alttext="C d with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cd</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions, causing the equilibrium to shift to favor the products.

content.answer: The molar solubility of <math alttext="C d F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CdF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in pure water is <math alttext="0.0585 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0585</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and adding <math alttext="N a F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> decreases this solubility because the equilibrium shifts to favor the precipitation of some <math alttext="C d F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CdF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
